cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to the processes and strategies for discovering new drugs with a special focus on current and emerging approaches for the rational design of drugs that are both effective and safe.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Art of Drug Discovery

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Student inquiries should be directed to the course coordinator: Dr. Rebecca Laposa, pcl102@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Lectures introduce students to prescribed and illicit drugs that affect the brain. Lectures cover drug pharmacology and explain how drugs alter mood, perception, cognition, and arousal by affecting different aspects of brain function. The societal impact of these prescribed and illicit drugs is also discussed. Note: This course is not intended for upper-year students in Life Sciences. Upper-year Life Science students interested in this content should look into PCL475H1 and/or PCL476H1 as the more appropriate choice.
cmCourseInfo.title: Drugs & the Brain

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Student inquiries should be directed to: pcl200@utoronto.ca. Please note this is a breadth course for students either outside of the Life Sciences or for students in year 1 interested in gaining an appreciation for drugs and the brain.

courses.name: Introduction to Pharmacology and Pharmacokinetic Principles

subjectPost.name: Focus in Pharmacology and Biomedical Toxicology

cmCourseInfo.description: A general introduction to the principles of pharmacology and pharmacokinetics. Topics include chemical (drug) absorption, distribution, biotransformation, elimination; the calculation of dosages and pharmacokinetic parameters, variability in drug response, adverse drug reactions and special interest topics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Pharmacology and Pharmacokinetic Principles
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BIO130H1/ BIOA01H3/ BIO152H5 and completion of at least 6.0 credits

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Student inquiries should be directed to: pcl201@utoronto.ca. Students in either Subject POSt code AEESCBASCO BASc-Engineering Sci (Nano Eng) or AEESCBASEB BASc in Eng Sci (Biomedical) will be provided exemption from required pre-requisite courses.

cmCourseInfo.description: There is a critical need for a breadth of understanding regarding its mechanism of action, pharmacological effects and its potential benefits and harms (short- and long-term). Students will gain a breadth of understanding in cannabis-related topics including pharmacology and toxicology, its role in mental health and addictions, medical use, drug policy and new drug development that stems from increased access to cannabis constituents. They will learn to differentiate myths and anecdotes from evidence-based knowledge. Going forward it is imperative that students spanning basic sciences through business, arts and engineering have a comprehensive understanding of these topics. PCL218H1 will give students for a variety of academic backgrounds a basic understanding of the health implications of cannabis which have broad implications for both our professional and personal lives.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cannabis the Drug

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Student inquiries should be directed to the undergraduate office: pcl218@utoronto.ca.

Please note this is a breadth course for students either outside of the Life Sciences or for students in year 1 interested in gaining an appreciation for cannabis and its pharmacology and toxicology.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered fully online per the course schedule (asynchronous).

The final exam will be delivered in-person during the scheduled final exam period.

courses.name: Research Experience in Pharmacology & Toxicology I

cmCourseInfo.description: A formal opportunity to gain hands-on experience and develop their skills within a research laboratory setting. Students will have a chance to become familiar and efficient at good lab practices, develop critical thinking and evaluation skills while applying their knowledge and developing trouble shooting skills to practical research questions. Students are required to participate in active research for the equivalent of a minimum of 60 hours of laboratory time. This course is Pass/Fail. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. NOTE: students are required to secure their own supervisor for the course. Permission of Faculty Supervisor and Department required. Additional student information resources and enrollment form for the course can be found on the Pharmacology & Toxicology website here: https://pharmtox.utoronto.ca/undergraduate-courses
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Experience in Pharmacology & Toxicology I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of at least 4.0 credits.
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Completion of at least first year of Life Sciences program.

courses.name: Research Experience in Pharmacology & Toxicology II

cmCourseInfo.description: Following experience from PCL297H1, this follow up course provides students an opportunity to expand their hands-on experience and skill set within a research laboratory setting. This course is only open to students who have completed PCL297H1 and wish to continue their research opportunity with the same supervisor. Students will continue to develop good lab practices, critical thinking and evaluation skills while applying their knowledge and trouble shooting skills to practical research questions. Students are required to participate in active research for the equivalent of a minimum of 60 hours of laboratory time. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. NOTE: students are required to secure their own supervisor for the course. Permission of Faculty Supervisor and Department required. Additional student information resources and enrollment form for the course can be found on the Pharmacology & Toxicology website here: https://pharmtox.utoronto.ca/undergraduate-courses
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Experience in Pharmacology & Toxicology II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PCL297H1. Students who have already completed another project course equivalent to or at a greater level than PCL297H1 can contact the Department.

Focus in Pharmacology and Biomedical Toxicology

cmCourseInfo.description: Lecturers use their own research to demonstrate how they approach a biological question. The lectures emphasize why one approach is chosen over other possible approaches, and explain the strengths and limitations of techniques. Following the one-hour lecture there is an interactive discussion of the experimental approach covered in the lecture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Experimental Approaches in Drug Discovery
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: One of PSL300H1/ PSL301H1/ BIO270H1/ BIO271H1, and completion of 9.0 credits. Students who do not meet the prerequisite are encouraged to contact the Department.

courses.name: Drug Development Pipeline I: In vitro

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will provide a learning experience that simulates the process, techniques, analysis and evaluation methods used for early-stage in vitro drug development. Modules will build on the student’s fundamental knowledge and will simulate and illustrate the thought processes and techniques that are used during new drug development in academic research institutes, clinical research organizations and pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies worldwide. Modules include target screening, cytotoxicity assays, transcriptional activation testing and metabolizing enzyme identification experiments. This experience will allow students to leverage their learned knowledge to improve their employability in this area, while honing their critical thinking and analytical skills. (Approximate Lab Materials Fee: $27)
cmCourseInfo.title: Drug Development Pipeline I: In vitro
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 9.0 credits including PSL300H1 and PSL301H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Student inquiries should be directed to the course coordinator: Dr. Anita Hamadani, anita.hamadanizadeh@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

This is an in-person laboratory course. The in-person tutorial section will take place per the course syllabus, as well as to act as course office hours.

NOTE: Due to the mandatory safety training required for this course, enrolment in this course will close after the first lecture week. Please contact undergrad.pharmtox@utoronto.ca for further details.

courses.name: Drug Development Pipeline II: In vivo

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will provide a learning experience that parallels and simulates the process, protocols, methods and evaluation tools used for later-stage in vivo drug development. Modules will build on the student’s fundamental knowledge and simulate the thought processes and techniques used during drug development in research institutes, clinical research organizations and pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies worldwide. Modules will include pharmacokinetic and pharmacogenetic screening approaches in model systems and humans, and students will participate in Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) studies. Students will also gain insight into current large-data computational research approaches in the pharmaceutical industry, broaching topics such as data science and bioinformatics. This experience will allow students to leverage their learned skills and knowledge to improve their comprehension and employability in this area, while honing critical thinking and analytical skills. (Approximate Lab Materials Fee: $27)
cmCourseInfo.title: Drug Development Pipeline II: In vivo
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSL300H1, PSL301H1, PCL201H1, PCL302H1

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces toxicology principles and the molecular basis underlying the toxicity of drugs and other chemicals. Lectures cover modulators of toxicity, toxicant-target interactions and the sequence of events that occur at a molecular level leading to impaired cell function.
cmCourseInfo.title: Molecular Toxicology Foundations
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BIO130H1/ BIOA01H3/ BIO152H5, PCL201H1, or Permission of the Department

cmCourseInfo.description: The routes and toxicokinetics/time course of toxicological insults disrupts and damages tissues and organs resulting in adverse outcomes, worsening clinical outcomes and triggering new pathologies and disorder. This course engages students in comprehensive and broad organ and system-based toxicology and its effects on human health.
cmCourseInfo.title: Integrative Toxicology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PCL201H1, PCL302H1, PCL381H1. Students who do not meet the prerequisites are encouraged to contact the Department.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will expand on both classical and cutting edge pharmacological strategies proposed to mitigate the consequences of altered signal transduction in cancer. Students will have the opportunity to develop knowledge on these molecular events and how they can be targeted to improve clinical outcomes. Students will integrate lecture material with assigned readings and assignments.
cmCourseInfo.title: Pharmacology of Cancer Signaling
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BCH210H1/ BCH242Y1/ [ CHM361H5(UTM) and CHM362H5(UTM)], [ BIOC12H3(UTSC) and BIOC13H3(UTSC)], CHMB62H3(UTSC), and completion of at least 9.0 credits. Students who do not meet the prerequisite are encouraged to contact the Department.

courses.name: Understanding the Role of Pharmacology and Toxicology in Society

cmCourseInfo.description: This service learning course explores issues surrounding the effects that pharmaceuticals and chemicals have in society. Specifically, it integrates pharmacology and toxicology with social, health and political issues as they relate to drug abuse and addiction. Students are required to interact and work with community partners during the semester (approx. 20hrs). Classroom discussions will integrate community experiences with lecture material. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Understanding the Role of Pharmacology and Toxicology in Society
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PCL201H1, (PSL300H1, PSL301H1)

Delivery Instructions

NOTE: This is a community engaged learning course. Due to the requirements for community partner placements, enrolment in this course will close early after the first week of class. Please contact undergrad.pharmtox@utoronto.ca for further details.

courses.name: Pharmacology and Toxicology in Drug Development

subjectPost.name: Specialist in Pharmacology and Biomedical Toxicology

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides the basic principles of drug development, with a primary focus on the application of fundamental principles of pharmacology and toxicology to the design of preclinical assays and early phase clinical trials. Students in the course will have the opportunity to engage in experiential learning in drug development projects for rare diseases.
cmCourseInfo.title: Pharmacology and Toxicology in Drug Development
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PCL201H1, PCL302H1

subjectPost.name: Focus in Pharmacology and Biomedical Toxicology
Focus in Pharmacology and Biomedical Toxicology

cmCourseInfo.description: A culmination of pharmacological principles discussing concepts of drug properties and their interactions within the body. The mechanism of action, pharmacological properties including clinical use and adverse effects of drugs acting on the autonomic nervous systems, cardiovascular, renal, respiratory, gastrointestinal and endocrine systems will be examined. Critical evaluation of primary literature and examination of clinical problem-based case studies will be integrated with lecture material through small group sessions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Systems Pharmacology I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PCL201H1, PCL302H1, (PSL300H1, PSL301H1)

subjectPost.name: Focus in Pharmacology and Biomedical Toxicology

cmCourseInfo.description: A culmination of pharmacological principles discussing concepts of drug properties and their interactions within the body. The mechanism of action, pharmacological properties including clinical use and adverse effects of drugs acting on the central nervous systems and immunological system; antimicrobial and cancer chemotherapeutic agents as well as the potential therapeutic use of endogenous/herbal compounds will be examined. Critical evaluation of primary literature and examination of clinical problem-based case studies will be integrated with lecture material through small group sessions.

subjectPost.name: Specialist in Pharmacology and Biomedical Toxicology

cmCourseInfo.description: This course affords students an opportunity for hands-on research experience in a laboratory or applied pharmacology setting. Students will work under the supervision of a faculty member and will submit a final written report and oral presentation. Enrollment is limited to students in ASSPE2340/ASSPE2082 programs and requires permission from the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology. It is the student’s responsibility to secure a placement with an approved supervisor before the course begins (a list of potential supervisors will be provided by the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology). Students will be registered in the course once their ballot form (obtained from the Department) is signed by an approved supervisor and approved by the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology. Eligible students will be contacted by the Department during the Winter term, occurring prior to their final year of study (i.e. 3rd year of study for most), with details and instructions to apply. Students are expected to spend approximately 200 hours towards this project but this will be project/supervisor dependent. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Project in Pharmacology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PCL201H1, PCL302H1, PCL367H1/ PCL368H1, STA288H1/ STA220H1/ PSY201H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

Delivery Instructions

Learning for this course is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. There are no formal lecture meetings as part of this course. Tutorials will be delivered per the meeting schedule/syllabus.

Enrollment is limited to students in ASSPE2340/ASSPE2573/ASSPE0605 programs and requires permission from the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology. It is the student’s responsibility to secure a placement with an approved supervisor before the course begins (a list of potential supervisors will be provided by the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology). cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines drugs whose primary effect is to alter the operation of the brain and mind (cognition, emotion). Key topics include the neurophysiology of: Pain, Anesthesia, Psychoactive Drug Effects, Addiction, Epilepsy, and Psychomotor Control. The brain mechanisms that mediate each of these processes or syndromes will be described along with pharmacological strategies to probe and regulate them. Chronic drug effects will be discussed to illustrate how the brain changes with ongoing exposure to different drugs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neuropsychopharmacology 1
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 9.0 credits

courses.name: The DNA Damage Response in Pharmacology and Toxicology

cmCourseInfo.description: Many anticancer drugs and environmental agents exert their cytotoxic effects through DNA damage. This course explores specific pharmacological and toxicological agents that damage DNA and discusses how mammalian cells respond to this DNA damage.
cmCourseInfo.title: The DNA Damage Response in Pharmacology and Toxicology

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores several contemporary topics in biomedical toxicology with an emphasis on how chemicals adversely affect human health. Lectures cover principles of toxicology and the mechanisms of toxicity of major groups of chemical toxicants and biological toxins, including heavy metals, industrial pollutants, biological toxins and nanomaterials.
cmCourseInfo.title: Toxicants of Concern
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 14.0 credits including PCL201H1, PCL302H1, PCL381H1 and PCL382H1. Students who do not meet the prerequisites are encouraged to contact the Department.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores several contemporary topics in biomedical and environmental toxicology with an emphasis on the applications and methodologies within toxicology. Course content includes risk assessments, adverse drug reaction monitoring, forensics and regulator toxicology.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Pharmacology and Toxicology

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Principles of Pharmacogenetics Theory and Practice

subjectPost.name: Specialist in Pharmacology and Biomedical Toxicology

cmCourseInfo.description: An opportunity to expand on innovative and unique topics in Pharmacology and Toxicology that are not already extensively addressed. The course will reveal the dynamic nature of the field and the diverse interests of our faculty. Students will be introduced to leading edge topics and research within the discipline of Pharmacology and Toxicology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Pharmacology and Toxicology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PCL302H1, one of STA288H1/ STA220H1/ PSY201H1, completion of 14.0 credits. Students who do not meet the prerequisite are encouraged to contact the Department.

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Principles of Pharmacogenetics Theory and Practice

This course will introduce basic pharmacogenetics concepts and provide opportunity for hands-on practice with the tools used within the field. Through applying genetic concepts, students will use research protocols to: (i) clean genetic data, (ii) use statistical inference to analyze unobserved genotypes, (iii) identify variants of relevance for drug response or unwanted effects of drugs, and (iv) calculate polygenic risk scores. Guest scientists will provide examples of the successful use of pharmacogenetics in the field of personalized medicine.

Student inquiries should be directed to the course department: undergrad.pharmtox@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Advanced Research in Pharmacology or Biomedical Toxicology

cmCourseInfo.description: Following experience from PCL472Y1 or PCL474Y1, this course provides students an opportunity to continue to expand and develop their research skills and knowledge within a research laboratory or applied pharmacology setting. Students will develop advanced collaboration skills, good lab practices, scientific literacy, critical thinking and evaluation skills while applying their knowledge and trouble shooting skills to practical research questions. Written and oral communication skills as well as laboratory skills will comprise course assessments. Students are required to participate in active research for the equivalent of a minimum of 60 hours of laboratory time. NOTE: As this is an opportunity to continue their experience within the same PCL472Y1/PCL474Y1 research laboratory/supervisor. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Research in Pharmacology or Biomedical Toxicology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PCL472Y1/ PCL474Y1

Delivery Instructions

This is an independent research project course with no formal lecture schedule. Students are required to secure their own supervisor for the course.

courses.name: Advanced Research in Pharmacology or Biomedical Toxicology

cmCourseInfo.description: Following experience from PCL472Y1 or PCL474Y1, this course provides students an opportunity to continue to expand and develop their research skills and knowledge within a research laboratory or applied pharmacology setting. Students will develop advanced collaboration skills, good lab practices, scientific literacy, critical thinking and evaluation skills while applying their knowledge and trouble shooting skills to practical research questions. Written and oral communication skills as well as laboratory skills will comprise course assessments. Students are required to participate in active research for the equivalent of a minimum of 60 hours of laboratory time. NOTE: As this is an opportunity to continue their experience within the same PCL472Y1/PCL474Y1 research laboratory/supervisor. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Research in Pharmacology or Biomedical Toxicology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PCL472Y1/ PCL474Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students enroll in this course through the Department. Student information and ballot form can be found on the departmental website here: https://pharmtox.utoronto.ca/undergraduate-courses. Please contact course coordinator: Dr. Hamadani at anita.hamadanizadeh@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

This is an independent research project course with no formal lecture schedule. Students are required to secure their own supervisor for the course.

courses.name: Advanced Research in Pharmacology or Biomedical Toxicology

cmCourseInfo.description: Following experience from PCL472Y1 or PCL474Y1, this course provides students an opportunity to continue to expand and develop their research skills and knowledge within a research laboratory or applied pharmacology setting. Students will develop advanced collaboration skills, good lab practices, scientific literacy, critical thinking and evaluation skills while applying their knowledge and trouble shooting skills to practical research questions. Written and oral communication skills as well as laboratory skills will comprise course assessments. Students are required to participate in active research and related activities for the equivalent of a minimum of 200 hours of laboratory time. NOTE: As this is an opportunity to continue their research, students are required to continue within the same PCL472Y1/PCL474Y1 research laboratory/supervisor. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
